I started helping a friend of mine develop a system to use drones for crop spraying, but he had to stop when he found out that if he were to use drone commercially, he had to have pilot's licence.  Even with a pre-programmed flight plan (with some serious safety systems in place), the fact that it was commercial operation meant that the person operating or responsible for the flying of the drone had to have a pilot's licence.  I think that the FAA is terrified of drones.

replies.context: It's more of the fact that the drone will be potentially be operating in the same airspace as airplanes with real people in them.   Pre-programmed can be more dangerous than active control simply because of unexpected occurrences (property next to his is being crop dusted, life flight landing near his property for some reason, etc).
I doubt airplanes are going to be flying in the same airspace as a drone crop duster, if they are, they are probably already crashing

Drones can fly up to 400' legally.  Life flight  helicopters routinely fly that low to the ground when near the point of landing.  Crop dusters also are easily within that same elevation.  So yes, there will be aircraft at the same elevations as drones.  That is the reason for the current VFR flight rules for drones and part of the reason that any commercial operation requires remote pilot certificate.  That is not the same as a Pilot License.

In the case of what we're were doing, the net operational elevation was about 12' above the crops.  At some point there has to be some measure of common sense applied.  We were developing a system that would have reduced the amount of pesticide/herbicide/fertilizer needed by using a very highly specific application instead of the massive over-spraying that most aerial application techniques create. It would have eliminated the need for leaving empty rows for tractor based spraying, which would have increased yield per acre.  It would have been far cheaper than crop dusters as well.

Then get a Remote Pilot Certificate.  They are fairly easy to obtain and require absolutely no class time or demonstration of skills.  All you need to do is show you can pass a test which basically only shows you understand the rules you are operating the drone within.

It's ridiculously expensive for its' purpose ($150 per 2 years, just for 'working' with a RC toy); and though it's nice to know how to read sectional charts, METARS, and other flying details, it's unnecessary for simple operation of a microprocessor-controlled drone.

Lol, 'working' with a RC toy.  Drones can be light and they can be big and heavy.  I've seen "RC toys" just about kill someone before (back before the days they were called drones, an operator lost control of a racing RC plane and it went into the crowd.  The prop chewed the guy up  way more than I would have ever thought possible for an RC Plane.  These toys can kill, especially the larger ones.
